text: Benedict de Spinoza, THE ETHICS
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (Ethica Ordine Geometrico Demonstrata)
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Translated by R. H. M. Elwes
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PART IV:  Of Human Bondage, or the Strength of the Emotions
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PREFACE
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Human infirmity in moderating and checking the emotions I name bondage:
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for, when a man is a prey to his emotions, he is not his own master, but
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: lies at the mercy of fortune: so much so, that he is often compelled,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: while seeing that which is better for him, to follow that which is worse.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Why this is so, and what is good or evil in the emotions, I propose to
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: show in this part of my treatise. But, before I begin, it would be well
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to make a few prefatory observations on perfection and imperfection,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: good and evil.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: When a man has purposed to make a given thing, and has brought it
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to perfection, his work will be pronounced perfect, not only by
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: himself, but by everyone who rightly knows, or thinks that he knows,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the intention and aim of its author. For instance, suppose anyone sees a
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: work (which I assume to be not yet completed), and knows that the aim
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the author of that work is to build a house, he will call the work
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imperfect; he will, on the other hand, call it perfect, as soon as he
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sees that it is carried through to the end, which its author had purposed
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for it. But if a man sees a work, the like whereof he has never seen
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: before, and if he knows not the intention of the artificer, he plainly
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cannot know, whether that work be perfect or imperfect. Such seems to
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be the primary meaning of these terms.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: But, after men began to form general ideas, to think out types of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: houses, buildings, towers, &c., and to prefer certain types to others,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it came about, that each man called perfect that which he saw agree
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with the general idea he had formed of the thing in question, and called
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imperfect that which he saw agree less with his own preconceived type,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: even though it had evidently been completed in accordance with the idea
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of its artificer.  This seems to be the only reason for calling natural
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: phenomena, which, indeed, are not made with human hands, perfect or
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imperfect: for men are wont to form general ideas of things natural, no
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: less than of things artificial, and such ideas they hold as types,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: believing that Nature (who they think does nothing without an object)
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: has them in view, and has set them as types before herself. Therefore,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: when they behold something in Nature, which does not wholly conform to
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the preconceived type which they have formed of the thing in question,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they say that Nature has fallen short or has blundered, and has left
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: her work incomplete. Thus we see that men are wont to style natural
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: phenomena perfect or imperfect rather from their own prejudices, than
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from true knowledge of what they pronounce upon.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Now we showed in the Appendix to Part I., that Nature does not work
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with an end in view. For the eternal and infinite Being, which we call
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God or Nature, acts by the same necessity as that whereby it exists. For
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we have shown, that by the same necessity of its nature, whereby it
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: exists, it likewise works (I:xvi.). The reason or cause why God or Nature
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: exists, and the reason why he acts, are one and the same.  Therefore,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as he does not exist for the sake of an end, so neither does he act for
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the sake of an end; of his existence and of his action there is neither
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: origin nor end. Wherefore, a cause which is called final is nothing else
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but human desire, in so far as it is considered as the origin or cause
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of anything. For example, when we say that to be inhabited is the final
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cause of this or that house, we mean nothing more than that a man,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceiving the conveniences of household life, had a desire to build a
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: house. Wherefore, the being inhabited, in so far as it is regarded as
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a final cause, is nothing else but this particular desire, which is
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: really the efficient cause; it is regarded as the primary cause,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: because men are generally ignorant of the causes of their desires.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: They are, as I have often said already, conscious of their own actions
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and appetites, but ignorant of the causes whereby they are determined
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to any particular desire. Therefore, the common saying that Nature
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sometimes falls short, or blunders, and produces things which are
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imperfect, I set down among the glosses treated of in the Appendix to
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Part 1.  Perfection and imperfection, then, are in reality merely modes
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of thinking, or notions which we form from a comparison among one
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another of individuals of the same species; hence I said above
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (II:Def.vi.), that by reality and perfection I mean the same thing.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: For we are wont to refer all the individual things in nature to one
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: genus, which is called the highest genus, namely, to the category of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Being, whereto absolutely all individuals in nature belong. Thus, in
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so far as we refer the individuals in nature to this category, and
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: comparing them one with another, find that some possess more of being or
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reality than others, we, to this extent, say that some are more perfect
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: than others. Again, in so far as we attribute to them anything implying
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: negation - as term, end, infirmity, etc., we, to this extent, call them
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imperfect, because they do not affect our mind so much as the things
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which we call perfect, not because they have any intrinsic deficiency,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or because Nature has blundered. For nothing lies within the scope of a
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thing's nature, save that which follows from the necessity of the nature
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of its efficient cause, and whatsoever follows from the necessity of the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature of its efficient cause necessarily comes to pass.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: As for the terms good and bad, they indicate no positive quality in
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things regarded in themselves, but are merely modes of thinking, or
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: notions which we form from the comparison of things one with another.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Thus one and the same thing can be at the same time good, bad, and
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: indifferent. For instance, music is good for him that is melancholy,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: bad for him that mourns; for him that is deaf, it is neither good nor
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: bad.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Nevertheless, though this be so, the terms should still be retained.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: For, inasmuch as we desire to form an idea of man as a type of human
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature which we may hold in view, it will be useful for us to retain
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the terms in question, in the sense I have indicated.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: In what follows, then, I shall mean by, "good" that, which we
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: certainly know to be a means of approaching more nearly to the type
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of human nature, which we have set before ourselves; by "bad," that
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which we certainly know to be a hindrance to us in approaching the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: said type.  Again, we shall that men are more perfect, or more imperfect,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in proportion as they approach more or less nearly to the said type.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: For it must be specially remarked that, when I say that a man passes
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from a lesser to a greater perfection, or vice versa, I do not mean
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that he is changed from one essence or reality to another; for instance,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a horse would be as completely destroyed by being changed into a man,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as by being changed into an insect. What I mean is, that we conceive the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thing's power of action, in so far as this is understood by its nature,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to be increased or diminished. Lastly, by perfection in general I shall,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as I have said, mean reality in other words, each thing's essence, in so
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: far as it exists, and operates in a particular manner, and without paying
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: any regard to its duration. For no given thing can be said to be more
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perfect, because it has passed a longer time in existence. The duration
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of things cannot be determined by their essence, for the essence of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things involves no fixed and definite period of existence; but everything,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whether it be more perfect or less perfect, will always be able to persist
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in existence with the same force wherewith it began to exist; wherefore, in
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this respect, all things are equal.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: DEFINITIONS.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I. By good I mean that which we certainly know to be useful to us.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: II. By evil I mean that which we certainly know to be a hindrance
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to us in the attainment of any good. (Concerning these terms see the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: foregoing preface towards the end.)
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: III. Particular things I call contingent in so far as, while regarding
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their essence only, we find nothing therein, which necessarily asserts
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their existence or excludes it.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: IV. Particular things I call possible in so far as, while regarding the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: causes whereby they must be produced, we know not, whether such causes
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be determined for producing them.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (In I:xxxiii.note.i., I drew no distinction between possible and
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contingent, because there was in that place no need to distinguish
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: them accurately.)
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: V. By conflicting emotions I mean those which draw a man in different
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: directions, though they are of the same kind, such as luxury and
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: avarice, which are both species of love, and are contraries, not
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by nature, but by accident.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: VI. What I mean by emotion felt towards a thing, future, present, and
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: past, I explained in III:xviii.,notes.i.,&ii., which see.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (But I should here also remark, that we can only distinctly conceive
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: distance of space or time up to a certain definite limit; that is, all
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: objects distant from us more than two hundred feet, or whose distance
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from the place where we are exceeds that which we can distinctly conceive,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: seem to be an equal distance from us, and all in the same plane; so also
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: objects, whose time of existing is conceived as removed from the present
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by a longer interval than we can distinctly conceive, seem to be all
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: equally distant from the present, and are set down, as it were, to the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: same moment of time.)
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: VII. By an end, for the sake of which we do something, I mean a desire.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: VIII. By virtue (virtus) and power I mean the same thing; that is
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (III:vii.), virtue, in so far as it is referred to man, is a man's
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature or essence, in so far as it has the power of effecting what
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: can only be understood by the laws of that nature.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: AXIOM.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: There is no individual thing in nature, than which there is not
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another more powerful and strong. Whatsoever thing be given, there is
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: something stronger whereby it can be destroyed.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROPOSITIONS.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. I. No positive quality possessed by a
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: false idea is removed by the presence of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: what is true, in virtue of its being true.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- Falsity consists solely in the privation of knowledge which
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: inadequate ideas involve (II:xxxv.), nor have they any positive
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: quality on account of which they are called false (II:xxxiii.);   contrariwise, in so far as they
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are referred to God, they are true
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (II:xxxii.).  Wherefore, if the positive quality possessed by a false
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: idea were removed by the presence of what is true, in virtue of its
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: being true, a true idea would then be removed by itself, which
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (IV:iii.) is absurd. Therefore, no positive quality possessed by a
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: false idea, &c. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.- This proposition is more clearly understood from II:xvi.Coroll.ii.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: For imagination is an idea, which indicates rather the present disposition
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the human body than the nature of the external body; not indeed
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: distinctly, but confusedly; whence it comes to pass, that the mind is
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: said to err. For instance, when we look at the sun, we conceive that it
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is distant from us about two hundred feet; in this judgment we err, so
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: long as we are in ignorance of its true distance; when its true distance
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is known, the error is removed, but not the imagination; or, in other
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: words, the idea of the sun, which only explains tho nature of that
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: luminary, in so far as the body is affected thereby: wherefore, though
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we know the real distance, we shall still nevertheless imagine the sun
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to be near us. For, as we said in III:xxxv.note, we do not imagine the sun
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to be so near us, because we are ignorant of its true distance, but because
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the mind conceives the magnitude of the sun to the extent that the body is
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affected thereby.  Thus, when the rays of the sun falling on the surface of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: water are reflected into our eyes, we imagine the sun as if it were in the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: water, though we are aware of its real position; and similarly other
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imaginations, wherein the mind is deceived whether they indicate the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: natural disposition of the body, or that its power of activity is
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: increased or diminished, are not contrary to the truth, and do not vanish
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: at its presence. It happens indeed that, when we mistakenly fear an evil,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the fear vanishes when we hear the true tidings; but the contrary also
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: happens, namely, that we fear an evil which will certainly come, and our
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fear vanishes when we hear false tidings; thus imaginations do not vanish
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: at the presence of the truth, in virtue of its being true, but because
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other imaginations, stronger than the first, supervene and exclude the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: present existence of that which we imagined, as I have shown in II:.xvii.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. II. We are only passive, in so far as
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we are apart of Nature, which cannot be
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceived by itself without other parts.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- We are said to be passive, when something arises in us, whereof
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we are only a partial cause (III:Def.ii.), that is (III:Def.i.), something
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which cannot be deduced solely from the laws of our nature. We are passive
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore in so far as we are a part of Nature, which cannot be conceived
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by itself without other parts. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. III. The force whereby a man persists
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in existing is limited, and is infinitely
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: surpassed by the power of external causes.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.-This is evident from the axiom of this part. For, when man is
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: given, there is something else - say A - more powerful; when A is given,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: there is something else - say B - more powerful than A, and so on to
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinity; thus the power of man is limited by the power of some other
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thing, and is infinitely surpassed by the power of external causes. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. IV. It is impossible, that man should
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not be a part of Nature, or that he should
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be capable of undergoing no changes, save
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: such as can be understood through his nature
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: only as their adequate cause.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- The power, whereby each particular thing, and consequently man,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: preserves his being, is the power of God or of Nature (I:xxiv.Coroll.);
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not in so far as it is infinite, but in so far as it can be explained by
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the actual human essence (III:vii.). Thus the power of man, in so far

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: such knowledge is concerned with what is

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: easily still, than desire for things
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that are present.

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.- I think I have now shown the reason, why men are moved by opinion
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: more readily than by true reason, why it is that the true knowledge of good
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and evil stirs up conflicts in the soul, and often yields to every kind of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: passion. This state of things gave rise to the exclamation of the poet:

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: The better path I gaze at and approve,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: The worse - I follow."
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Ecclesiastes seems to have had the same thought in his mind, when he says,

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: "He who increaseth knowledge increaseth sorrow." I have not written the

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: do in restraining the emotions, and what is beyond her power. I have said,

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. XVIII. Desire arising from pleasure is,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other conditions being equal, stronger than
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: desire arising from pain.

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.- In these few remarks I have explained the causes of human infirmity
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and inconstancy, and shown why men do not abide by the precepts of reason.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which of the emotions are in harmony with the rules of human reason, and
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which of them are contrary thereto.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: But, before I begin to prove my Propositions in detailed geometrical
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fashion, it is advisable to sketch them briefly in advance, so that
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: everyone may more readily grasp my meaning.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: As reason makes no demands contrary to nature, it demands, that every
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man should love himself, should seek that which is useful to him - I mean,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that which is really useful to him, should desire everything which really
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: brings man to greater perfection, and should, each for himself, endeavour
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as far as he can to preserve his own being. This is as necessarily true,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as that a whole is greater than its part. (Cf. III:iv.)
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Again, as virtue is nothing else but action in accordance with the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: laws of one's own nature (IV:Def.viii.), and as no one endeavours to
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: preserve his own being, except in accordance with the laws of his own
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature, it follows, first, that the foundation of virtue is the endeavour
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to preserve one's own being, and that happiness consists in man's power
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of preserving, his own being; secondly, that virtue is to be desired for
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: its own sake, and that there is nothing more excellent or more useful to
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: us, for the sake of which we should desire it; thirdly and lastly that
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: suicides are weak-minded, and are overcome by external causes repugnant to
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their nature. Further, it follows from Postulate iv. Part.II., that we can
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: never arrive at doing without all external things for the preservation of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: our being or living, so as to have no relations with things
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which are outside ourselves. Again, if we consider our mind, we see that
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: our intellect would be more imperfect, if mind were alone, and could
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understand nothing besides itself. There are, then, many things outside
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ourselves, which are useful to us, and are, therefore, to be desired.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Of such none can be discerned more excellent, than those which are in
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: entire agreement with our nature. For if, for example, two individuals
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of entirely the same nature are united, they form a combination twice
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as powerful as either of them singly.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Therefore, to man there is nothing more useful than man - nothing,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I repeat, more excellent for preserving their being can be wished for
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by men, than that all should so in all points agree, that the minds and
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: bodies of all should form, as it were, one single mind and one single
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body, and that all should, with one consent, as far as they are able,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endeavour to preserve their being, and all with one consent seek what is
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: useful to them all. Hence, men who are governed by reason - that is, who
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: seek what is useful to them in accordance with reason, desire for
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: themselves nothing, which they do not also desire for the rest of mankind,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and, consequently, are just, faithful, and honourable in their conduct.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Such are the dictates of reason, which I purposed thus briefly to
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: indicate, before beginning to prove them in greater detail. I have taken
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this course, in order, if possible, to gain the attention of those who
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: believe, that the principle that every man is bound to seek what is useful
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for himself is the foundation of impiety, rather than of piety and virtue.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Therefore, after briefly showing that the contrary is the case, I go
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: on to prove it by, the same method, as that whereby I have hitherto
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proceeded.

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. XIX. Every man, by the laws of his
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature, necessarily desires or shrinks
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from that which he deems to be good or bad.

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 4

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. XX. The more every man endeavours,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and is able to seek what is useful to him -
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in other words, to preserve his own being -
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the more is he endowed with virtue; on the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contrary, in proportion as a man neglects

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to seek what is useful to him, that is, to
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man to persist in his own being. Wherefore, the more a man endeavours,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and is able to preserve his own being, the more is he endowed with virtue,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: preserve his own being, he is wanting in power. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.- No one, therefore, neglects seeking his own good, or preserving his
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that is, to escape a greater evil by incurring, a lesser; or, lastly,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understanding, and judges nothing to be useful to itself, save such
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things as conduce to understanding (by the foregoing Prop.). But the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind (II:xli.&Note) cannot possess certainty concerning anything,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: except in so far as it has adequate ideas, or (what by II:xl.Note,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is the same thing) in so far as it reasons. Therefore we know nothing
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to be good or evil save such things as really conduce, &c. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. XXVIII. The mind's highest good is
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the knowledge of God, and the mind's
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: highest virtue is to know God.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- The mind is not capable of understanding anything higher than God,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that is (I:Def.vi.), than a Being absolutely infinite, and without which
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (I:xv.) nothing can either be or be conceived; therefore (IV:xxvi.,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: &xxvii.), the mind's highest utility or (IV:Def.i.) good is the knowledge
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of God. Again, the mind is active, only in so far as it understands, and
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: only to the same extent can it be said absolutely to act virtuously. The
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind's absolute virtue is therefore to understand. Now, as we have already
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: shown, the highest that the mind can understand is God; therefore the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: highest virtue of the mind is to understand or to know God. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. XXIX. No individual thing, which is
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: entirely different from our own nature,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: can help or check our power of activity, and
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: absolutely nothing can do us good or harm,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: unless it has something in common with our nature.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- The power of every individual thing, and consequently the power of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man, whereby he exists and operates, can only be determined by an
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: individual thing (I:xxviii.), whose nature (II:vi.) must be understood
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: through the same nature as that, through which human nature is conceived.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Therefore our power of activity, however it be conceived, can be determined
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and consequently helped or hindered by the power of any other individual
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thing, which has something in common with us, but not by the power of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: anything, of which the nature is entirely different from our own; and
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: since we call good or evil that which is the cause of pleasure or pain
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (IV:viii.), that is (III:xi.Note), which increases or diminishes, helps
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or hinders, our power of activity; therefore, that which is entirely,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: different from our nature can neither be to us good nor bad. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. XXX. A thing cannot be bad for us
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: through the quality which it has in common
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with our nature, but it is bad for us in so
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: far as it is contrary to our nature.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- We call a thing bad when it is the cause of pain (IV:viii.), that
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is (by the Def., which see in III:xi.Note), when it diminishes or checks
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: our power of action. Therefore, if anything were bad for us through that
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: quality which it has in common with our nature, it would be able
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: itself to diminish or check that which it has in common with our nature,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which (III:iv.) is absurd. Wherefore nothing can be bad for us through
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that quality which it has in common with us, but, on the other hand, in
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so far as it is bad for us, that is (as we have just shown), in so far as
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it can diminish or check our power of action, it is contrary to our nature.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. XXXI. In so far as a thing is in harmony
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with our nature, it is necessarily good.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- In so far as a thing is in harmony with our nature, it cannot be
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: bad for it. It will therefore necessarily be either good or indifferent.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: If it be assumed that it be neither good nor bad, nothing will follow from
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: its nature (IV:Def.i.), which tends to the preservation of our nature,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that is (by the hypothesis), which tends to the preservation of the thing
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: itself; but this (III:vi.) is absurd; therefore, in so far as a thing is
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in harmony with our nature, it is necessarily good. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.- Hence it follows, that, in proportion as a thing is in harmony
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with our nature, so is it more useful or better for us, and vice versa, in
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proportion as a thing is more useful for us, so is it more in harmony with
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: our nature. For, in so far as it is not in harmony with our nature, it
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will necessarily be different therefrom or contrary thereto. If different,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it can neither be good nor bad (IV:xxix.); if contrary, it will be contrary
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to that which is in harmony with our nature, that is, contrary to what is
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: good - in short, bad. Nothing, therefore, can be good, except in so far as
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it is in harmony with our nature; and hence a thing is useful, in proportion
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as it is in harmony with our nature, and vice versa. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. XXXII. In so far as men are a prey
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to passion, they cannot, in that respect,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be said to be naturally in harmony.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof. Things, which are said to be in harmony naturally, are understood to
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: agree in power (III:vii.), not in want of power or negation, and
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consequently not in passion (III:iii.Note); wherefore men, in so far as
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they are a prey to their passions, cannot be said to be naturally in
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: harmony. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.- This is also self-evident; for, if we say that white and black only
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: agree in the fact that neither is red, we absolutely affirm that the do not
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: agree in any respect. So, if we say that a man and a stone only agree in the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fact that both are finite - wanting in power, not existing by the necessity
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of their own nature, or, lastly, indefinitely surpassed by the power of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: external causes - we should certainly affirm that a man and a stone are in
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: no respect alike; therefore, things which agree only in negation, or in
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: qualities which neither possess, really agree in no respect.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. XXXIII. Men can differ in nature,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in so far as they are assailed by those
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotions, which are passions, or passive
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: states; and to this extent one and the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: same man is variable and inconstant.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- The nature or essence of the emotions cannot be explained solely
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: through our essence or nature (III:Def.i.&ii.), but it must be defined by
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the power, that is (III:vii.), by the nature of external causes in
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: comparison with our own; hence it follows, that there are as many kinds of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: each emotion as there are external objects whereby we are affected
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (III:lvi.), and that men may be differently affected by one and the same
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: object (III:li), and to this extent differ in nature; lastly, that one and
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the same man may be differently affected towards the same object, and may
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore be variable and inconstant. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. XXXIV. In so far as men are assailed
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by emotions which are passions, they can be
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contrary one to another.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- A man, for instance Peter, can be the cause of Paul's feeling pain,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: because he (Peter) possesses something similar to that which Paul hates
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (III:xvi.), or because Peter has sole possession of a thing which Paul also
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: loves (III:xxxii.&Note), or for other causes (of which the chief are
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: enumerated in III:lv.Note) ; it may therefore happen that Paul should hate
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Peter (Def. of Emotions: vii.), consequently it may easily happen also, that
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Peter should hate Paul in return, and that each should endeavour to do the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other an injury, (III:xxxix.), that is (IV:xxx.), that they should be
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contrary one to another. But the emotion of pain is always a passion
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or passive state (III:lix.); hence men, in so far as they are assailed by
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotions which are passions, can be contrary one to another. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.- I said that Paul may hate Peter, because he conceives that Peter
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: possesses something which he (Paul) also loves; from this it seems, at first
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sight, to follow, that these two men, through both loving the same thing,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and, consequently, through agreement of their respective natures, stand in
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: one another's way; if this were so, II:xxx. and II:xxxi. would be untrue.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: But if we give the matter our unbiased attention, we shall see that the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: discrepancy vanishes. For the two men are not in one another's way in
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: virtue of the agreement of their natures, that is, through both loving the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: same thing, but in virtue of one differing from the other. For, in so far
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as each loves the same thing, the love of each is fostered thereby
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (III:xxxi.), that is (Def. of the Emotions: vi.) the pleasure of each is
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fostered thereby. Wherefore it is far from being the case, that they are
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: at variance through both loving the same thing, and through the agreement
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in their natures. The cause for their opposition lies, as I have said,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: solely in the fact that they are assumed to differ. For we assume that
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Peter has the idea of the loved object as already in his possession, while
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Paul has the idea of the loved object as lost. Hence the one man will be
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affected with pleasure, the other will be affected with pain, and thus they
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will be at variance one with another. We can easily show in like manner,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that all other causes of hatred depend solely on differences, and not on
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the agreement between men's natures.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. XXXV. In so far only as men live
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in obedience to reason, do they always
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily agree in nature.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- In so far as men are assailed by emotions that are passions, they
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: can be different in nature (IV:xxxiii.), and at variance one with another.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: But men are only said to be active, in so far as they act in obedience to
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason (III:iii.); therefore, what so ever follows from human nature in so
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: far as it is defined by reason must (III:Def.ii.) be understood solely
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: through human nature as its proximate cause. But, since every man by the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: laws of his nature desires that which he deems good, and endeavours to
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: remove that which he deems bad (IV:xix.); and further, since that which we,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in accordance with reason, deem good or bad, necessarily is good
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or bad (II:xli.); it follows that men, in so far as they live in obedience
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to reason, necessarily do only such things as are necessarily good for
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: human nature, and consequently for each individual man (IV:xxxi.Coroll.);
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in other words, such things as are in harmony with each man's nature.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Therefore, men in so far as they live in obedience to reason, necessarily
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: live always in harmony one with another. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary I - There is no individual thing in nature, which is
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: more useful to man, than a man who lives in obedience to reason. For that
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thing is to man most useful, which is most in harmony with his nature
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (IV:xxxi.Coroll.); that is, obviously, man. But man acts absolutely
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: according to the laws of his nature, when he lives in obedience to reason
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (III:Def.ii.), and to this extent only is always necessarily in harmony
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with the nature of another man (by the last Prop.); wherefore among
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: individual things nothing is more useful to man, than a man who lives in
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: obedience to reason. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary II.- As every man seeks most that which is useful to him, so are
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: men most useful one to another. For the more a man seeks what is useful to
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: him and endeavours to preserve himself, the more is he endowed with virtue
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (IV:xx.), or, what is the same thing (IV:Def.viii.), the more is he endowed
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with power to act according to the laws of his own nature, that is to live
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in obedience to reason. But men are most in natural harmony, when they live
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in obedience to reason (by the last Prop.); therefore (by the foregoing
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Coroll.) men will be most useful one to another, when each seeks most that
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which is useful to him. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.- What we have just shown is attested by experience so conspicuously,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that it is in the mouth of nearly everyone: "Man is to man a God." Yet it
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rarely happens that men live in obedience to reason, for things are so
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ordered among them, that they are generally envious and troublesome one to
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another. Nevertheless they are scarcely able to lead a solitary life,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so that the definition of man as a social animal has met with general
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: assent; in fact, men do derive from social life much more convenience than
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: injury. Let satirists then laugh their fill at human affairs, let
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: theologians rail, and let misanthropes praise to their utmost the life of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: untutored rusticity, let them heap contempt on men and praises on beasts;
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: when all is said, they will find that men can provide for their wants much
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: more easily by mutual help, and that only by uniting their forces can they
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: escape from the dangers that on every side beset them: not to say how much
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: more excellent and worthy of our knowledge it is, to study the actions of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: men than the actions of beasts. But I will treat of this more at
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: length elsewhere.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. XXXVI. The highest good of those
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: who follow virtue is common to all,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and therefore all can equally rejoice
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therein.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- To act virtuously is to act in obedience with reason (IV:xxiv.),
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and whatsoever we endeavour to do in obedience to reason is to understand
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (IV:xxvi.); therefore (IV:xxviii.) the highest good for those who follow
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: after virtue is to know God; that is (II:xlvii.&Note) a good which is
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: common to all and can be possessed. by all men equally, in so far as they
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are of the same nature. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.- Someone may ask how it would be, if the highest good of those who
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: follow after virtue were not common to all? Would it not then follow, as
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: above (IV:xxxiv.), that men living in obedience to reason, that is
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (IV:xxxv.), men in so far as they agree in nature, would be at variance
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: one with another? To such an inquiry, I make answer, that it follows not
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: accidentally but from the very nature of reason, that main's highest good
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is common to all, inasmuch as it is deduced from the very essence of man,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in so far as defined by reason; and that a man could neither be, nor be
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceived without the power of taking pleasure in this highest good. For
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it belongs to the essence of the human mind (II:xlvii.), to have an
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: adequate knowledge of the eternal and infinite essence of God.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. XXXVII. The good which every man,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: who follows after virtue, desires for
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: himself he will also desire for other
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: men, and so much the more, in proportion
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as he has a greater knowledge of God.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- Men, in so far as they live in obedience to reason, are most
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: useful to their fellow men (IV:xxxv;Coroll.i.); therefore (IV:xix.),
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we shall in obedience to reason necessarily endeavour to bring about that

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: men should live in obedience to reason. But the good which every man, in
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so far as he is guided by reason, or, in other words, follows after virtue,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: desires for himself, is to understand (IV:xxvi.); wherefore the good, which
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: each follower of virtue seeks for himself, he will desire also for others.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Again, desire, in so far as it is referred to the mind, is the very
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: essence of the mind (Def. of the Emotions, i.); now the essence of the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind consists in knowledge (III:xi.), which involves the knowledge of God
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (II:xlvii.), and without it (I:xv.), can neither be, nor be conceived;
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, in proportion as the mind's essence involves a greater knowledge
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of God, so also will be greater the desire of the follower of virtue, that
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other men should possess that which he seeks as good for himself. Q.E.D.

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will love more constantly, if he sees that others love it also (III:xxxi.);
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he will therefore endeavour that others should love it also; and as the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: good in question is common to all, and therefore all can rejoice therein,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he will endeavour, for the same reason, to bring about that all should
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de
