title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as his own enjoyment of the good is greater.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note 1- He who, guided by emotion only, endeavours to cause others to love
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: what he loves himself, and to make the rest of the world live according to
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his own fancy, acts solely by impulse, and is, therefore, hateful,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: especially, to those who take delight in something different, and
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: accordingly study and, by similar impulse, endeavour, to make men live in
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: accordance with what pleases themselves. Again, as the highest good sought
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by men under the guidance of emotion is often such, that it can only be
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: possessed by a single individual, it follows that those who love it are not
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consistent in their intentions, but, while they delight to sing its praises,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fear to be believed. But he, who endeavours to lead men by reason, does not
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: act by impulse but courteously and kindly, and his intention is always
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consistent. Again, whatsoever we desire and do, whereof we are the cause
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in so far as we possess the idea of God, or know God, I set down to
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Religion. The desire of well-doing, which is engendered by a life
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: according to reason, I call piety. Further, the desire, whereby a
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man living according to reason is bound to associate others with
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: himself in friendship, I call honour (Honestas); by honourable I mean
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that which is praised by men living according to reason, and by base
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I mean that which is repugnant to the gaining of friendship. I have also
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: shown in addition what are the foundations of a state; and the difference
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: between true ,virtue and infirmity may be readily gathered from what I
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have said; namely, that true virtue is nothing else but living in
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: accordance with reason; while infirmity is nothing else but man's
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: allowing himself to be led by things which are external to himself,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and to be by them determined to act in a manner demanded by the general
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: disposition of things rather than by his own nature considered solely
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in itself.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Such are the matters which I engaged to prove in IV:xviii., whereby it
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is plain that the law against the slaughtering of animals is founded rather
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: on vain superstition and womanish pity than on sound reason. The rational
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: quest of what is useful to us further teaches us the necessity of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: associating ourselves with our fellow men, but - not with beasts, or things,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whose nature is different from our own; we have the same rights in respect
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to them as they have in respect to us. Nay, as everyone's right is defined
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by his virtue, or power, men have far greater rights over beasts than
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: beasts have over men. Still I do not deny that beasts feel: what I deny is,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that we may not consult our own advantage and use them as we please,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: treating them in the way which best suits us; for their nature is not like
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ours, and their emotions are naturally different from human emotions
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (III:Ivii.Note). It remains for me to explain what I mean by, just and
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: unjust, sin and merit. On these points see the following note.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note II.- In the Appendix to Part I. I undertook to explain praise and
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: blame, merit and sin, justice and injustice.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Concerning praise and blame I have spoken in III:xxix.Note: the time
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: has now come to treat of the remaining terms. But I must first say a few
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: words concerning man in the state of nature and in society.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Every man exists by sovereign natural right, and, consequently, by
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sovereign natural right performs those actions which follow from the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessity of his own nature; therefore by sovereign natural right every man
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: judges what is good and what is bad, takes care of his own advantage
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: according to his own disposition (IV:xix. and IV:xx.), avenges the wrongs
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: done to him (III:xl.Coroll. ii.), and endeavours to preserve that which he
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: loves and to destroy - that which he hates (III:xxviii.). Now, if men lived
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: under the guidance of reason, everyone would remain in possession of this
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his right, without any injury being done to his neighbour V:xxxv.Coroll.i.).
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: But seeing that they are a prey to their emotions, which far surpass human
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: power or virtue (IV:vi.), they are often drawn in different directions, and
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: being at variance one with another (IV:xxxiii., xxxiv.), stand in need of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mutual help (IV:xxxv.Note). Wherefore, in order that men may live together
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in harmony, and may aid one another, it is necessary that they should
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: forego their natural right, and, for the sake of security, refrain from
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: all actions which can injure their fellow-men. The way in which this end
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: can be obtained, so that men who are necessarily a prey to their emotions
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (IV:iv.Coroll.), inconstant, and diverse, should be able to render each
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other mutually secure, and feel mutual trust, is evident from IV:vii. and
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: III:xxxix. It is there shown, that an emotion can only be restrained by an
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotion stronger than, and contrary to itself, and that men avoid inflicting
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: injury through fear of incurring a greater injury themselves.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: On this law society can be established, so long as it keeps in its own
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hand the right, possessed by everyone, of avenging injury, and pronouncing
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: on good and evil; and provided it also possesses the power to lay down a
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: general rule of conduct, and to pass laws sanctioned, not by reason, which
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is powerless in restraining emotion, but by threats (IV:xvii.Note). Such a
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: society established with laws and the power of preserving itself is called
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a State, while those who live under its protection are called citizens. We
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: may readily understand that there is in the state of nature nothing, which
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by universal consent is pronounced good or bad; for in the state of nature
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: everyone thinks solely of his own advantage, and according to his
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: disposition, with reference only to his individual advantage, decides
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: what is good or bad, being bound by no law to anyone besides himself.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: In the state of nature, therefore, sin is inconceivable; it can only
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: exist in a state, where good and evil are pronounced on by common consent,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and where everyone is bound to obey the State authority. Sin, then,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is nothing else but disobedience, which is therefore punished by the right
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the State only. Obedience, on the other hand, is set down as merit,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: inasmuch as a man is thought worthy of merit, if he takes delight in the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: advantages which a State provides.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Again, in the state of nature, no one is by common consent master of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: anything, nor is there anything in nature, which can be said to belong to
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: one man rather than another: all things are common to all. Hence, in the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: state of nature, we can conceive no wish to render to every man his own,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or to deprive a man of that which belongs to him; in other words, there is
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nothing in the state of nature answering to justice and injustice. Such
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ideas are only possible in a social state, when it is decreed by common
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consent what belongs to one man and what to another.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: From all these considerations it is evident, that justice and
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: injustice, sin and merit, are extrinsic ideas, and not attributes which
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: display the nature of the mind. But I have said enough.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. XXXVIII. Whatsoever disposes the human
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body, so as to render it capable of being
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affected in an increased number of ways, or
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of affecting external bodies in an increased
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: number of ways, is useful to man ; and is so,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in proportion as the body is thereby rendered
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: more capable of being affected or affecting
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other bodies in an increased number of ways;
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: capable in this respect is hurtful to man.

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: also the mind's capability of perception (II:xiv.); therefore, whatsoever
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thus disposes the body and thus renders it capable, is necessarily good or
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: useful (IV:xxvi., IV:xxvii.); and is so in proportion to the extent to
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which it can render the body capable; contrariwise (II:xiv., IV:xxvi.,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: IV:xxvii.), it is hurtful, if it renders the body in this respect less
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: capable. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. XXXIX. Whatsoever brings about
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the preservation of the proportion of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: motion and rest, which the parts of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the human body mutually possess, is
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: good; contrariwise, whatsoever causes
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a change in such proportion is bad.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- The human body needs many other bodies for its preservation
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (II:Post.iv.). But that which constitutes the specific reality (forma)
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of a human body is, that its parts communicate their several motions
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: one to another in a certain fixed proportion (Def. before Lemma iv. after
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: II:xiii.). Therefore, whatsoever brings about the preservation of the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proportion between motion and rest, which the parts of the human body
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mutually possess, preserves the specific reality of the human body, and
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consequently renders the human body capable of being affected in many ways
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and of affecting external bodies in many ways; consequently it is good
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (by the last Prop.). Again, whatsoever brings about a change in the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: aforesaid proportion causes the human body to assume another specific
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: character, in other words (see Preface to this Part towards the end,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: though the point is indeed self-evident), to be destroyed, and
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consequently totally incapable of being affected in an increased
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: numbers of ways; therefore it is bad. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.- The extent to which such causes can injure or be of service to the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind will be explained in the Fifth Part. But I would here remark that I
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consider that a body undergoes death, when the proportion of motion and
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rest which obtained mutually among its several parts is changed. For I do
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not venture to deny that a human body, while keeping the circulation of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the blood and other properties, wherein the life of a body is thought to
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consist, may none the less be changed into another nature totally different
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from its own. There is no reason, which compels me to maintain that a body
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: does not die, unless it becomes a corpse; nay, experience would seem to
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: point to the opposite conclusion. It sometimes happens, that a man
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: undergoes such changes, that I should hardly call him the same. As I have
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: heard tell of a certain Spanish poet, who had been seized with sickness,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and though he recovered therefrom yet remained so oblivious of his past
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: life, that he would not believe the plays and tragedies he had
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: child, if he had also forgotten his native tongue. If this instance seems

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: been an infant by the analogy of other men. However, I prefer to leave such

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: questions undiscussed, lest I should give ground to the superstitious for

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: raising new issues.

title: Ethics — Part 4

title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: bad but good: contrariwise, pain in
title: Ethics — Part 4

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and preventing its becoming excessive, and hindering the body's

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. XLIV. Love and desire may be excessive.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- Love is pleasure, accompanied by the idea of an external cause
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (Def_of_Emotions:vi.); therefore stimulation, accompanied by the idea of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: an external cause is love (III:xi.Note); hence love maybe excessive.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Again, the strength of desire varies in proportion to the emotion from
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which it arises (III:xxxvii.). Now emotion may overcome all the rest of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: men's actions (IV:vi.); so, therefore, can desire, which arises from the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: same emotion, overcome all other desires, and become excessive, as we
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: showed in the last proposition concerning stimulation.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.- Mirth, which I have stated to be good, can be conceived more easily
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: than it can be observed. For the emotions, whereby we are daily assailed,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are generally referred to some part of the body which is affected more than
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the rest; hence the emotions are generally excessive, and so fix the mind
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the contemplation of one object, that it is unable to think of others;
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cases, where one and the same emotion remains obstinately fixed. We
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sometimes see men so absorbed in one object, that, although it be not
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: present, they think they have it before them; when this is the case with a
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man who is not asleep, we say he is delirious or mad; nor are those persons
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: who are inflamed with love, and who dream all night and all day about
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nothing but their mistress, or some woman, considered as less mad, for
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they are made objects of ridicule. But when a miser thinks of nothing but
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: gain or money, or when an ambitious man thinks of nothing but glory, they
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are not reckoned to be mad, because they are generally harmful, and are
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thought worthy of being hated. But, in reality, Avarice, Ambition, Lust,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: &c., are species of madness, though they may not be reckoned among diseases.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. XLV. Hatred can never be good.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- When we hate a man, we endeavour to destroy him (III.xxxix.),
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that is (IV:xxxvii.), we endeavour to do something that is bad.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Therefore, &c. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: N.B. Here, and in what follows, I mean by hatred only hatred towards men.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary I.- Envy, derision, contempt, anger, revenge, and other emotions
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attributable to hatred, or arising therefrom, are bad; this is evident from
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: III:xxxix. and IV:xxxvii.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary II.- Whatsoever we desire from motives of hatred is base, and in
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a State unjust. This also is evident from III:xxxix., and from the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: definitions of baseness and injustice in IV:xxxvii.Note.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.- Between derision (which I have in Coroll. I. stated to be bad) and
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: laughter I recognize a great difference. For laughter, as also jocularity,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is merely pleasure; therefore, so long as it be not excessive, it is in
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: itself good (IV:xli.). Assuredly nothing forbids man to enjoy himself,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: save grim and gloomy superstition. For why is it more lawful to satiate
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: one's hunger and thirst than to drive away one's melancholy? I reason, and
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have convinced myself as follows: No deity, nor anyone else, save the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: envious, takes pleasure in my infirmity and discomfort, nor sets down to my
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: virtue the tears, sobs, fear, and the like, which axe signs of infirmity of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: spirit; on the contrary, the greater the pleasure wherewith we are affected,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the greater the perfection whereto we pass; in other words, the more must
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we necessarily partake of the divine nature. Therefore, to make use of what
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: comes in our way, and to enjoy it as much as possible (not to the point of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: satiety, for that would not be enjoyment) is the part of a wise man. I say
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it is the part of a wise man to refresh and recreate himself with moderate
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and pleasant food and drink, and also with perfumes, with the soft beauty
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of growing plants, with dress, with music, with many sports, with theatres,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and the like, such as every man may make use of without injury to his
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: neighbour. For the human body is composed of very numerous parts, of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: diverse nature, which continually stand in need of fresh and varied
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nourishment, so that the whole body may be equally capable of performing
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: all the actions, which follow from the necessity of its own nature; and,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consequently, so that the mind may also be equally capable of -
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understanding many things simultaneously. This way of life, then, agrees
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: best with our principles, and also with general practice; therefore, if
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: there be any question of another plan, the plan we have mentioned is the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: best, and in every way to be commended. There is no need for me to set
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: forth the matter more clearly or in more detail.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. XLVI. He, who lives under the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: guidance of reason, endeavours, as
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: far as possible, to render back love,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or kindness, for other men's hatred,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: anger, contempt, &c., towards him.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- All emotions of hatred are bad (IV:xlv.Coroll.i.); therefore he who
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: lives under the guidance of reason will endeavour, as far as possible, to
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: avoid being assailed by, such emotions (IV:xix.); consequently, he will
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: also endeavour to prevent others being so aspect (IV:xxxvii.). But hatred
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is increased by being reciprocated, and can be quenched by love III:xliii.),
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so that hatred may pass into love (III:xliv.); therefore he who lives under
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the guidance of reason will endeavour to repay hatred with love, that is,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with kindness. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.- He who chooses to avenge wrongs with hatred is assuredly, wretched.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: But he, who strives to conquer hatred with love, fights his battle in joy
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and confidence; he withstands many as easily as one, and has very little
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: need of fortune's aid. Those whom he vanquishes yield joyfully, not through
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: failure, but through increase in their powers; all these consequences
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: follow so plainly from the mere definitions of love and understanding,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that I have no need to prove them in detail.

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. XLVII. Emotions of hope and fear
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cannot be in themselves good.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- Emotions of hope and fear cannot exist without pain. For fear is
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: can restrain excessive pleasure (IV:xliii.). Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.- We may add, that these emotions show defective knowledge and an
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: absence of power in the mind; for the same reason confidence, despair, joy,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and disappointment are signs of a want of mental power. For although
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: confidence and joy are pleasurable emotions, they, nevertheless imply a
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: preceding, pain, namely, hope and fear. Wherefore the more we endeavour to
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be guided by reason, the less do we depend on hope; we endeavour to free
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ourselves from fear, and, as far as we can, to dominate fortune, directing
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: our actions by the sure counsels of wisdom.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and disparagement are always bad.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- These emotions (see Def. of the Emotions, xxi., xxii.) are
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: repugnant to reason; and are therefore (IV. xxvi., IV:xxvii.) bad. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. XLIX. Over-esteem is apt to
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: render its object proud.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- If we see that any one rates us too highly, for love's sake,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we are apt to become elated (III:xli.), or to be pleasurably affected
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Def. of the Emotions:xxx.); the good which we hear of ourselves we readily
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: believe (III:xxv.); and therefore, for love's sake, rate ourselves too
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: highly; in other words, we are apt to become proud. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. L. Pity, in a man who lives
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: under the guidance of reason, is in
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: itself bad and useless.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- Pity (Def. of the Emotions:xviii.) is a pain, and therefore
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for certain to be good (IV:xxvii.); thus, in a man who lives under the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: guidance of reason, pity in itself is useless and bad. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.- He who rightly realizes, that all things follow from the necessity
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and rules of nature, will not find anything worthy of hatred, derision, or
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to reason, but can agree therewith

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and arise therefrom.

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 4

title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from reason, and that which arises

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. LV. Extreme pride or dejection
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: indicates extreme ignorance of self.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- This is evident from Def. of the Emotions:xxviii. and xxix.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. LVI. Extreme pride or dejection
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: indicates extreme infirmity of spirit.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- The first foundation of virtue is self-preservation
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (IV:xxii.Coroll.) under the guidance of reason (IV:xxiv.). He, therefore,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: who is ignorant of himself, is ignorant of the foundation of all virtues,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and consequently of all virtues. Again, to act virtuously is merely to
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: act under the guidance of reason (IV:xxiv.): now he, that acts under the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: guidance of reason, must necessarily know that he so acts (III:xliii.).
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Therefore he who is in extreme ignorance of himself, and consequently of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: all virtues, acts least in obedience to virtue; in other words
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (IV:Def.viii.), is most infirm of spirit. Thus extreme pride or dejection
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: indicates extreme infirmity of spirit. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.- Hence it most clearly follows, that the proud and the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: dejected specially fall a prey to the emotions.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.- Yet dejection can be more easily corrected than pride; for the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: latter being a pleasurable emotion, and the former a painful emotion, the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasurable is stronger than the painful (IV:xviii.).
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. LVII. The proud man delights in the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: company of flatterers and parasites,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but hates the company of the high-minded.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- Pride is pleasure arising from a man's over estimation of himself
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (Def. of the Emotions:xxviii. and vi.); this estimation the proud man will
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endeavour to foster by all the means in his power (III:xiii.Note); he will
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore delight in the company of flatterers and parasites (whose
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: character is too well known to need definition here), and will avoid the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: company of high-minded men, who value him according to his deserts. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.- It would be too long a task to enumerate here all the evil results
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of pride, inasmuch as the proud are a, prey to all the emotions, though to
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: none of them less than to love and pity. I cannot, however, pass over in
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: silence the fact, that a man may be called proud from his underestimation
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of other people; and, therefore, pride in this sense may be defined as
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasure arising from the false opinion, whereby a man may consider
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: himself superior to his fellows. The dejection, which is the opposite
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: quality to this sort of pride, may be defined as pain arising from the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: false opinion, whereby a man may think himself inferior to his fellows.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Such being the ease, we can easily see that a proud man is necessarily
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: envious (III:xli.Note), and only takes pleasure in the company, who fool
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his weak mind to the top of his bent, and make him insane instead of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: merely foolish.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Though dejection is the emotion contrary to pride, yet is the dejected
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man very near akin to the proud man. For, inasmuch as his pain arises
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from a comparison between his own infirmity and other men's power or
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: virtue, it will be removed, or, in other words, he will feel pleasure, if
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his imagination be occupied in contemplating other men's faults; whence
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: arises the proverb, "The unhappy are comforted by finding fellow-sufferers."
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Contrariwise, he will be the more pained in proportion as he thinks
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: himself inferior to others; hence none are so prone to envy as the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: dejected, they are specially keen in observing men's actions, with a
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: view to fault-finding rather than correction, in order to reserve their
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: praises for dejection, and to glory therein, though all the time with a
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: dejected air. These effects follow as necessarily from the said emotion,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as it follows from the nature of a triangle, that the three angles are
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: equal to two right angles. I have already said that I call these and
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: similar emotions bad, solely in respect to what is useful to man. The
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: laws of nature have regard to nature's general order, whereof man is but
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a part. I mention this, in passing, lest any should think that I have
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wished to set forth the faults and irrational deeds of men rather than
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the nature and properties of things. For, as I said in the preface to the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: third Part, I regard human emotions and their properties as on the same
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: footing with other natural phenomena. Assuredly human emotions indicate
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the power and ingenuity, of nature, if not of human nature, quite as fully,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as other things which we admire, and which we delight to contemplate.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: But I pass on to note those qualities in the emotions, which bring
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: advantage to man, or inflict injury upon him.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. LVIII. Honour (gloria) is not repugnant
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to reason, but may arise therefrom.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.-This is evident from Def. of the Emotions:xxx., and also from the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: definition of an honourable man (IV:xxxvii.Note.i.).
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.- Empty honour, as it is styled, is self- approval, fostered only by
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the good opinion of the populace; when this good opinion ceases there
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ceases also the self-approval, in other words, the highest object of each
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man's love (IV:lii.Note); consequently, he whose honour is rooted in
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: popular approval must, day by day, anxiously strive, act, and scheme in
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: order to retain his reputation. For the populace is variable and
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: inconstant, so that, if a reputation be not kept up, it quickly withers
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: away. Everyone wishes to catch popular applause for himself, and readily
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: represses the fame of others. The object of the strife being estimated as
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the greatest of all goods, each combatant is seized with a fierce desire
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to put down his rivals in every possible way, till he who at last comes
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: out victorious is more proud of having done harm to others than of having
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: done good to himself. This sort of honour, then, is really empty, being
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nothing.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: The points to note concerning shame (pudor) may easily be inferred
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from what was said on the subject of mercy and repentance. I will only
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: add that shame, like compassion, though not a virtue, is yet good, in so
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: far as it shows, that the feeler of shame is really imbued with the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: desire to live honourably; in the same way as suffering is good, as
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: showing that the injured part is not mortified. Therefore, though a man
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: who feels shame is sorrowful, he is yet more perfect than he, who is
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: shameless, and has no desire to live honourably.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Such are the points which I undertook to remark upon concerning the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotions of pleasure and pain; as for the desires, they are good or bad
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: according as they spring from good or evil emotions. But all, in so far
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as they are engendered in us by, emotions wherein the mind is passive,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are blind (as is evident from what was said in IV:xliv.Note), and would
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be useless, if men could easily, be induced to live by the guidance of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason only, as I will now briefly, show.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. LIX. To all the actions, whereto we
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are determined by emotion wherein the mind
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is passive; we can be determined without
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotion by reason.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- To act rationally, is nothing else (III:iii. and III:Def.ii.)
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but to perform those actions, which follow from the necessity, of our
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature {to persist} considered in itself alone. But pain is bad, in so
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: far as it diminishes or checks the power of action (IV:xli.); wherefore
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we cannot by pain be determined to any action, which we should be unable
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to perform under the guidance of reason. Again, pleasure is bad only
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in so far as it hinders a man's capability for action (IV:xli., IV:xliii.);
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore to this extent we could not be determined by, it to any action,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which we could not perform under the guidance of reason. Lastly, pleasure,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in so far as it is good, is in harmony with reason (for it consists in the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fact that a man's capability for action is increased or aided); nor is the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind passive therein, except in so far as a man's power of action is not
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: increased to the extent of affording him an adequate conception of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: himself and his actions (III:iii., &Note).
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Wherefore, if a man who is pleasurably affected be brought to such a
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: state of perfection, that he gains an adequate conception of himself and
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his own actions, he will be equally, nay more, capable of those actions,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to which he is determined by emotion wherein the mind is passive. But all
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotions are attributable to pleasure, to pain, or to desire (Def. of the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Emotions:iv. explanation); and desire (Def. of the Emotions:i.) is nothing
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: else but the attempt to act; therefore, to all actions, &c. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Another Proof.- A given action is called bad, in so far as it arises
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from one being affected by hatred or any evil emotion. But no action,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: considered in itself alone, is either good or bad (as we pointed out in
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the preface to Pt. IV.), one and the same action being sometimes good,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sometimes bad; wherefore to the action which is sometimes bad, or arises
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from some evil emotion, we may be led by reason (IV:xix.). Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.- An example will put this point in a clearer light. The action of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: striking, in so far as it is considered physically, and in so far as we
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: merely look to the fact that a man raises his arm, clenches his fist, and
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: moves his whole arm violently downwards, is a virtue or excellence which
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is conceived as proper to the structure of the human body. If, then, a man,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: moved by anger or hatred, is led to clench his fist or to move his arm,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this result takes place (as we showed in Pt.II.), because one and the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: same action can be associated with various mental images of things;
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore we may be determined to the performance of one and the same
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: action by confused ideas, or by clear and distinct ideas. Hence it is
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: evident that every desire which springs from emotion, wherein the mind is
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: passive, would become useless, if men could be guided by reason. Let us
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: now see why desire which arises from emotion, wherein the mind is passive,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is called by us blind.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. LX. Desire arising from a pleasure
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or pain, that is not attributable, to
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the whole body, but only to one or certain
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: parts thereof, is without utility in
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: respect to a man as a whole.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- Let it be assumed, for instance, that A, a part of a body, is so
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: strengthened by some external cause, that it prevails over the remaining
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: parts (IV:vi.). This part will not endeavour to do away with its own
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: powers, in order that the other parts of the body may perform its office;
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for this it would be necessary for it to have a force or power of doing
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: away with its own powers, which (III:vi.) is absurd. The said part, and,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consequently, the mind also, will endeavour to preserve its condition.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Wherefore desire arising from a pleasure of the kind aforesaid has no
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: utility in reference to a man as a whole. If it be assumed, on the other
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hand, that the part, A, be checked so that the remaining parts prevail,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it may be proved in the same manner that desire arising from pain has no
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: utility in respect to a man as a whole. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.- As pleasure is generally (IV:xliv.Note) attributed to one part
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the body, we generally desire to preserve our being with out taking
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: into consideration our health as a whole: to which it may be added, that
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the desires which have most hold over us (IV:ix.) take account of the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: present and not of the future.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. LXI. Desire which springs from
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason cannot be excessive.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- Desire (Def. of the Emotions:i.) considered absolutely is the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: actual essence of man, in so far as it is conceived as in any way
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: determined to a particular activity by some given modification of itself.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Hence desire, which arises from reason, that is (III:iii.), which is
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: engendered in us in so far as we act, is the actual essence or nature of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man, in so far as it is conceived as determined to such activities as are
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: adequately conceived through man's essence only (III:Def.ii.). Now, if
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: such desire could be excessive, human nature considered in itself alone
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: would be able to exceed itself, or would be able to do more than it can,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a manifest contradiction. Therefore, such desire cannot be excessive. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. LXII. In so far as the mind conceives
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a thing under the dictates of reason, it is
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affected equally, whether the idea be of a
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thing future, past, or present.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- Whatsoever the mind conceives under the guidance of reason, it
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceives under the form of eternity or necessity (II:xliv.Coroll.ii.),
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and is therefore affected with the same certitude (II:xliii.&Note).
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Wherefore, whether the thing be present, past, or future, the mind
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceives it under the same necessity and is affected with the same
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: certitude; and whether the idea be of something present, past, or future,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it will in all cases be equally true (II:xli.); that is, it will always
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: possess the same properties of an adequate idea (II:Def.iv.); therefore, in
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so far as the mind conceives things under the dictates of reason, it is
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affected in the same manner, whether the idea be of a thing future, past,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or present. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.- If we could possess an adequate knowledge of the duration of things,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and could determine by reason their periods of existence, we should
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contemplate things future with the same emotion as things present; and
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the mind would desire as though it were present the good which it
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceived as future; consequently it would necessarily neglect a lesser
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: good in the present for the sake of a greater good in the future, and
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: would in no wise desire that which is good in the present but a source of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: evil in the future, as we shall presently show. However, we can have but
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a very inadequate knowledge of the duration of things (II:xxxi.) and the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: periods of their existence (II:xliv.Note) we can only determine by
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imagination, which is not so powerfully affected by the future as by the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: present. Hence such true knowledge of good and evil as we possess is
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: merely abstract or general, and the judgment which we pass on the order
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of things and the connection of causes, with a view to determining what
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is good or bad for us in the, present, is rather imaginary than real.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Therefore it is nothing wonderful, if the desire arising from such
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge of good and evil, in so far as it looks on into the future, be
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: more readily checked than the desire of things which are agreeable at the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: present time. (Cf. IV:xvi.)
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. LXIII. He who is led by fear,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and does good in order to escape evil,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is not led by reason.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- All the emotions which are attributable to the mind as active,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or in other words to reason, are emotions of pleasure and desire (III:lix.);
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, he who is led by fear, and does good in order to escape evil,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is not led by reason.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.- Superstitions persons, who know better how to rail at vice than
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: how to teach virtue, and who strive not to guide men by reason, but so
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to restrain them that they would rather escape evil than love virtue,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have no other aim but to make others as wretched as themselves; wherefore
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it is nothing wonderful, if they be generally troublesome and odious to
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their fellow-men.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.- Under desire which springs from reason, we seek good directly,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and shun evil indirectly.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- Desire which springs from reason can only spring from a pleasurable
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotion, wherein the mind is not passive (III:lix.), in other words, from
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a pleasure which cannot be excessive (IV:lxi.), and not from pain;
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wherefore this desire springs from the knowledge of good, not of evil
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (IV:viii.); hence under the guidance of reason we seek good directly and
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: only by implication shun evil. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.- This Corollary may be illustrated by the example of a sick and a
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: healthy man. The sick man through fear of death eats what he naturally
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: shrinks from, but the healthy man takes pleasure in his food, and thus
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: gets a better enjoyment out of life, than if he were in fear of death,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and desired directly to avoid it. So a judge, who condemns a criminal
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to death, not from hatred or anger but from love of the public
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: well-being, is guided solely by reason.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. LXIV. The knowledge of evil is
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: an inadequate knowledge.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- The knowledge of evil (IV:viii.) is pain, in so far as we are
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conscious thereof. Now pain is the transition to a lesser perfection
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (Def. of the Emotions:iii.) and therefore cannot be understood through
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man's nature (III:vi.,& II:vii.); therefore it is a passive state
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (III.Def.ii.) which (III:iii.) depends on inadequate ideas; consequently
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the knowledge thereof (II:xxix.), namely, the knowledge of evil, is
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: inadequate. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.- Hence it follows that, if the human mind possessed only
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: adequate ideas, it would form no conception of evil.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. LXV. Under the guidance of reason we
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: should pursue the greater of two goods and
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the lesser of two evils.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- A good which prevents our enjoyment of a greater good is in
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reality an evil; for we apply the terms good and bad to things, in so
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: far as we compare them one with another (see preface to this Part);
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, evil is in reality a lesser good; hence under the guidance of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason we seek or pursue only the greater good and the lesser evil. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.- We may, under the guidance of reason, pursue the lesser evil
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as though it were the greater good, and we may shun the lesser good,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which would be the cause of the greater evil. For the evil, which is
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: here called the lesser, is really good, and the lesser good is really
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: evil, wherefore we may seek the former and shun the latter. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. LXVI. We may, under the guidance of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason, seek a greater good in the future
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in preference to a lesser good in the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: present, and we may seek a lesser evil in
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the present in preference to a greater evil
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the future.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: "Maltim praesens minus prae majori futuro." (Van Vloten).  Bruder reads: "Malum praesens minus, quod
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: causa est faturi alicujus mali." The last word of the latter is an obvious misprint, and is
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: corrected by the Dutch translator into "majoris boni." (Pollock, p. 268, note.)
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- If the mind could have an adequate knowledge of things future,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it would be affected towards what is future in the same way as towards
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: what is present (IV:lxii.); wherefore, looking merely to reason, as in
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this proposition we are assumed to do, there is no difference, whether
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the greater good or evil be assumed as present, or assumed as future;
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hence (IV:lxv.) we may seek a greater good in the future in preference
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to a lesser good in the present, &c. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.- We may, under the guidance of reason, seek a lesser evil in
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the present, because it is the cause of a greater good in the future,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and we may shun a lesser good in the present, because it is the cause
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of a greater evil in the future. This Corollary is related to the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: foregoing Proposition as the Corollary to IV:lxv. is related to the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: said IV:lxv.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.- If these statements be compared with what we have pointed out
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: concerning the strength of the emotions in this Part up to Prop. xviii.,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we shall readily see the difference between a man, who is led solely by
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotion or opinion, and a man, who is led by reason. The former, whether
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will or no, performs actions whereof he is utterly ignorant; the latter is
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his own master and only performs such actions, as he knows are of primary
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: importance in life, and therefore chiefly, desires; wherefore I call the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: former a slave, and the latter a free man, concerning whose disposition
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and manner of life it will be well to make a few observations.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. LXVII. A free man thinks of death
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: least of all things; and his wisdom is
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a meditation not of death but of life.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- A free man is one who lives under the guidance of reason, who is
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not led by fear (IV:lxiii.), but who directly desires that which is good
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (IV:lxiii.Coroll.), in other words (IV:xxiv.), who strives to act, to live,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and to preserve his being on the basis of seeking his own true advantage;
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wherefore such an one thinks of nothing less than of death, but his wisdom
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is a meditation of life. Q.E.D
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. LXVIII. If men were born free,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they would, so long as they remained free,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: form no conception of good and evil.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- I call free him who is led solely by reason; he, therefore, who
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is born free, and who remains free, has only adequate ideas; therefore
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (IV:lxiv.Coroll.) he has no conception of evil, or consequently (good
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and evil being correlative) of good. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.- It is evident, from IV:iv., that the hypothesis of this Proposition
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is false and inconceivable, except in so far as we look solely to the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature of man, or rather to God; not in so far as the latter is infinite,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but only in so far as he is the cause of man's existence.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: This, and other matters which we have already proved, seem to have
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: been signifieded by Moses in the history of the first man. For in that
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: narrative no other power of God is conceived, save that whereby he
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: created man, that is the power wherewith he provided solely for man's
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: advantage; it is stated that God forbade man, being free, to eat of the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: tree of the knowledge of good and evil, and that, as soon as man should
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have eaten of it, he would straightway fear death rather than desire to
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: live. Further, it is written that when man had found a wife, who was in
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: entire harmony with his nature, he knew that there could be nothing in
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature which could be more useful to him; but that after he believed the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: beasts to be like himself, he straightway began to imitate their emotions
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (III:xxvii.), and to lose his freedom; this freedom was afterwards
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: recovered by the patriarchs, led by the spirit of Christ; that is, by the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: idea of God, whereon alone it depends, that man may be free, and desire for
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: others the good which he desires for himself, as we have shown above
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (IV:xxxii.).
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. LXIX. The virtue of a free man is seen
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to be as great, when it declines dangers,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as when it overcomes them.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- Emotion can only be checked or removed by an emotion contrary to
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: itself, and possessing more power in restraining emotion (IV:vii.). But
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: blind daring and fear are emotions, which can be conceived as equally
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: great (IV:v. and IV:iii.): hence, no less virtue or firmness is required
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in checking daring than in checking fear (III:lix.Note); in other words
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (Def. of the Emotions:xl. and xli.), the free man shows as much virtue,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: when he declines dangers, as when he strives to overcome them. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.- The free man is as courageous in timely retreat as in combat;
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or, a free man shows equal courage or presence of mind, whether he elect
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to give battle or to retreat.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.- What courage (animositas) is, and what I mean thereby, I explained
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in III:lix.Note. By danger I mean everything, which can give rise to any
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: evil, such as pain, hatred, discord, &c.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. LXX. The free man, who lives among the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ignorant, strives, as far as he can, to avoid
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: receiving favours from them.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- Everyone judges what is good according to his disposition
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (III:xxxix.Note); wherefore an ignorant man, who has conferred a benefit
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: on another, puts his own estimate upon it, and, if it appears to be
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: estimated less highly by the receiver, will feel pain (III:xlii.). But
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de
