text: the free man only desires to join other men to him in friendship
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (IV:xxxvii.), not repaying their benefits with others reckoned as of like
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: value, but guiding himself and others by the free decision of reason,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and doing only such things as he knows to be of primary importance.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Therefore the free man, lest be should become hateful to the ignorant, or
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: follow their desires rather than reason, will endeavour, as far as he can,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to avoid receiving their favours.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.- I say, as far as he can. For though men be ignorant, yet are they
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: men, and in cases of necessity could afford us human aid, the most
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: excellent of all things: therefore it is often necessary to accept favours
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from them, and consequently to repay such favours in kind; we must,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, exercise caution in declining favours, lest we should have the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: appearance of despising those who bestow them, or of being, from
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: avaricious motives, unwilling to requite them, and so give ground for
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: offence by the very fact of striving to avoid it. Thus, in declining
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: favours, we must look to the requirements of utility and courtesy.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. LXXI. Only free men are thoroughly
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: grateful one to another.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- Only free men are thoroughly useful one to another, and
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: associated among themselves by the closest necessity of friendship
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (IV:xxxv.,&Coroll.i.), only such men endeavour, with mutual zeal of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: love, to confer benefits on each other (IV:xxxvii.), and, therefore,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: only they are thoroughly grateful one to another. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.- The goodwill, which men who are led by blind desire have for one
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another, is generally a bargaining or enticement, rather than pure goodwill.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Moreover, ingratitude is not an emotion. Yet it is base, inasmuch as
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it generally shows, that a man is affected by excessive hatred, anger,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pride, avarice, &c. He who, by reason of his folly, knows not how to
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: return benefits, is not ungrateful, much less he who is not gained over
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by the gifts of a courtesan to serve her lust, or by a thief to conceal
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his thefts, or by any similar persons. Contrariwise, such an one shows
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a constant mind, inasmuch as he cannot by an gifts be corrupted, to his
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: own or the general hurt.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. LXXII. The free man never acts fraudulently,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but always in good faith.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- If it be asked: What should a man's conduct be in a case where
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he could by breaking faith free himself from the danger of present death?
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Would not his plan of self-preservation completely persuade him to deceive?
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: This may be answered by pointing out that, if reason persuaded him to act
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thus, it would persuade all men to act in a similar manner, in which case
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason would persuade men not to agree in good faith to unite their forces,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or to have laws in common, that is, not to. have any general laws, which is
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: absurd.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. LXXIII. The man, who is guided by reason,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is more free in a State, where he lives under
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a general system of law, than in
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: solitude, where he is independent.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.- The man, who is guided by reason, does not obey through fear
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (IV:Ixiii.): but, in so far as he endeavours to preserve his being
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: according to the dictates of reason, that is (IV:lxvi.Note), in so far
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as he endeavours to live in freedom, he desires to order his life
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: according to the general good (IV:xxxvii.), and, consequently (as we
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: showed in IV:xxxvii.Note.ii.), to live according to the laws of his
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: country. Therefore the free man, in order to enjoy greater freedom,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: desires to possess the general rights of citizenship. Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.- These and similar observations, which we have made on man's true
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: freedom, may be referred to strength, that is, to courage and nobility
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of character (III:lix.Note). I do not think it worth while to prove
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: separately all the properties of strength; much less need I show, that he
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that is strong hates no man, is angry with no man, envies no man, is
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: indignant with no man, despises no man, and least of all things is proud.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: These propositions, and all that relate to the true way of life and
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: religion, are easily proved from IV:xxxvii. and IV:xlvi.; namely, that
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hatred should be overcome with love, and that every man should desire for
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: others the good which he seeks for himself. We may also repeat what
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we drew attention to in the note to IV:I., and in other places; namely,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that the strong man has ever first in his thoughts, that all things
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: follow from the necessity of the divine nature; so that whatsoever he
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: deems to be hurtful and evil, and whatsoever, accordingly, seems to him
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: impious, horrible, unjust, and base, assumes that appearance owing to his
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: own disordered, fragmentary, and confused view of the universe. Wherefore
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he strives before all things to conceive things as they really are, and
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to remove the hindrances to true knowledge, such as are hatred, anger,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: envy, derision, pride, and similar emotions, which I have mentioned above.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Thus he endeavours, as we said before, as far as in him lies, to do good,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and to go on his way rejoicing. How far human virtue is capable of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attaining to such a condition, and what its powers may be, I will prove
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the following Part.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: APPENDIX.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: What have said in this Part concerning the right way of life has not been
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: arranged, so as to admit of being seen at one view, but has been set forth
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: piece-meal, according as I thought each Proposition could most readily be
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: deduced from what preceded it. I propose, therefore, to rearrange my
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: remarks and to bring them under leading heads.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I. All our endeavours or desires so follow from the necessity of our
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature, that they can be understood either through it alone, as their
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proximate cause, or by virtue of our being a part of nature, which cannot
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be adequately conceived through itself without other individuals.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: II. Desires, which follow from our nature in such a manner, that they can
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be understood through it alone, are those which are referred to the mind,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in so far as the latter is conceived to consist of adequate ideas: the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: remaining desires are only referred to the mind, in so far as it conceives
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things inadequately, and their force and increase are generally defined
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not by the power of man, but by the power of things external to us:
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wherefore the former are rightly called actions, the latter passions, for
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the former always indicate our power, the latter, on the other hand, show
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: our infirmity and fragmentary knowledge.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: III. Our actions, that is, those desires which are defined by man's power
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or reason, are always good. The rest maybe either good or bad.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: IV. Thus in life it is before all things useful to perfect the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understanding or reason, as far as we can, and in this alone man's
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: highest happiness or blessedness consists, indeed blessedness is nothing
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: else but the contentment of spirit, which arises from the intuitive
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge of God: now, to perfect the understanding is nothing else
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but to understand God, God's attributes, and the actions which follow
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from the necessity of his nature. Wherefore of a man, who is led by reason,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the ultimate aim or highest desire, whereby he seeks to govern all his
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fellows, is that whereby he is brought to the adequate conception of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: himself and of all things within the scope of his intelligence.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: V. Therefore, without intelligence there is not rational life: and things
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are only good, in so far as they aid man in his enjoyment of the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: intellectual life, which is defined by intelligence. Contrariwise,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whatsoever things hinder man's perfecting of his reason, and capability
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to enjoy the rational life, are alone called evil.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: VI. As all things whereof man is the efficient cause are necessarily good,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: no evil can befall man except through external causes; namely, by virtue
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of man being a part of universal nature, whose laws human nature is
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: compelled to, obey, and to conform to in almost infinite ways.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: VII. It is impossible, that man should not be a part of nature, or that
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he should not follow her general order; but if he be thrown among
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: individuals whose nature is in harmony with his own, his power of action
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will thereby be aided and fostered, whereas, if he be thrown among such as
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are but very little in harmony with his nature, he will hardly be able to
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: accommodate himself to them without undergoing a great change himself.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: VIII. Whatsoever in nature we deem to be evil, or to be capable of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: injuring our faculty for existing and enjoying the rational life, we may
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endeavour to remove in whatever way seems safest to us; on the other hand,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whatsoever we deem to be good or useful for preserving our being, and
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: enabling us to enjoy the rational life, we may appropriate to our use and
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: employ as we think best. Everyone without exception may, by sovereign
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: right of nature, do whatsoever he thinks will advance his own interest.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: IX. Nothing can be in more harmony with the nature of any given thing
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: than other individuals of the same species; therefore (cf. vii.) for man
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the preservation of his being and the enjoyment of the rational life
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: there is nothing more useful than his fellow-man who is led by reason.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Further, as we know not anything among individual things which is more
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: excellent than a man led by reason, no man can better display the power of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his skill and disposition, than in so training men, that they come at last
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to live under the dominion of their own reason.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: X. In so far as men are influenced by envy or any kind of hatred, one
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: towards another, they are at variance, and are therefore to be feared in
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proportion, as they are more powerful than their fellows.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XI. Yet minds are not conquered by force, but by love and high-mindedness.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XII. It is before all things useful to men to associate their ways of life,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to bind themselves together with such bonds as they think most fitted to
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: gather them all into unity, and generally to do whatsoever serves to
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: strengthen friendship.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XIII. But for this there is need of skill and watchfulness. For men are
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: diverse (seeing that those who live under the guidance of reason are few),
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: yet are they generally envious and more prone to revenge than to sympathy.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: No small force of character is therefore required to take everyone as he
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is, and to restrain one's self from imitating the emotions of others. But
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: those who carp at mankind, and are more skilled in railing at vice than
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in instilling virtue, and who break rather than strengthen men's
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: dispositions, are hurtful both to themselves and others. Thus many from
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: too great impatience of spirit, or from misguided religious zeal, have
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: preferred to live among brutes rather than among men; as boys or youths,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: who cannot peaceably endure the chidings of their parents, will enlist as
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: soldiers and choose the hardships of war and the despotic discipline in
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: preference to the comforts of home and the admonitions of their father:
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: suffering any burden to be put upon them, so long as they may spite
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their parents.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XIV. Therefore, although men are generally governed in everything by their
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: own lusts, yet their association in common brings many more advantages
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: than drawbacks. Wherefore it is better to bear patiently the wrongs they
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: may do us, and to strive to promote whatsoever serves to bring about
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: harmony and friendship.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XV. Those things, which beget harmony, are such as are attributable to
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: justice, equity, and honourable living. For men brook ill not only what is
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: unjust or iniquitous, but also what is reckoned disgraceful, or that a man
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: should slight the received customs of their society. For winning love those
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: qualities are especially necessary which have regard to religion and piety
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (cf. IV:xxxvii.Notes.i., &.ii.; IV:xlvi.Note; and IV:lxxiii.Note).
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XVI. Further, harmony is often the result of fear: but such harmony is
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: insecure. Further, fear arises from infirmity of spirit and moreover
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: belongs not to the exercise of reason: the same is true of compassion,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: though this latter seems to bear a certain resemblance to piety.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XVII. Men are also gained over by liberality, especially such as have
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not the means to buy what is necessary to sustain life. However, to give
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: aid to every poor man is far beyond the power and the advantage of any
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: private person. For the riches of any private person are wholly inadequate
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to meet such a call. Again, an individual man's resources of character
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are too limited for him to be able to make all men his friends. Hence
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: providing for the poor is a duty, which falls on the State as a whole,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and has regard only to the general advantage.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XVIII. In accepting favours, and in returning gratitude our duty must be
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wholly different (cf. IV:lxx.Note; IV:lxxi. Note).
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XIX. Again, meretricious love, that is, the lust of generation arising
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from bodily beauty, and generally every sort of love, which owns anything
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: save freedom of soul as its cause, readily passes into hate; unless indeed,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: what is worse, it is a species of madness; and then it promotes discord
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rather than harmony (cf. III:xxxi.Coroll.).
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XX. As concerning marriage, it is certain that this is in harmony with
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason, if the desire for physical union be not engendered solely by
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: bodily beauty, but also by the desire to beget children and to train them
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: up wisely; and moreover, if the love of both, to wit, of the man and of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the woman, is not caused by bodily beauty only, but also by freedom of soul.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXI. Furthermore, flattery begets harmony; but only by means of the vile
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: offence of slavishness or treachery. None are more readily taken with
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: flattery than the proud, who wish to be first, but are not.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXII. There is in abasement a spurious appearance of piety and
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: religion. Although abasement is the opposite to pride, yet is he that
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: abases himself most akin to the proud (IV:lvii.Note).
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXIII. Shame also brings about harmony, but only in such matters as cannot
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be hid. Further, as shame is a species of pain, it does not concern the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: exercise of reason.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXIV. The remaining emotions of pain towards men are directly opposed
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to justice, equity, honour, piety, and religion; and, although
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: indignation seems to bear a certain resemblance to equity, yet is life
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but lawless, where every man may pass judgment on another's deeds, and
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: vindicate his own or other men's rights.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXV. Correctness of conduct (modestia), that is, the desire of pleasing
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: men which is determined by reason, is attributable to piety (as we said
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in IV:xxxvii.Note.i.). But, if it spring from emotion, it is ambition,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or the desire whereby, men, under the false cloak of piety, generally
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: stir up discords and seditions. For he who desires to aid his fellows.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: either in word or in deed, so that they may together enjoy the highest
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: good, he, I say, will before all things strive to, win them over with
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: love: not to draw them into admiration, so that a system may be called
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: after his name, nor to give any cause for envy. Further, in his
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conversation he will shrink from talking of men's faults, and will be
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: careful to speak but sparingly of human infirmity: but he will dwell at
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: length on human virtue or power, and the way whereby it may be perfected.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Thus will men be stirred not by fear, nor by aversion, but only by the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotion of joy, to endeavour, so far as in them lies, to live in
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: obedience to reason.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXVI. Besides men, we know of no particular thing in nature in whose mind
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we may rejoice, and whom we can associate with ourselves in friendship or
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: any sort of fellowship; therefore, whatsoever there be in nature besides
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man, a regard for our advantage does not call on us to preserve, but to
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: preserve or destroy according to its various capabilities, and to adapt
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to our use as best we may.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXVII. The advantage which we derive from things external to us, besides
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the experience and knowledge which we acquire from observing them, and
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from recombining their elements in different forms, is principally the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: preservation of the body; from this point of view, those things are most
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: useful which can so feed and nourish the body, that all its parts may
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rightly fulfil their functions. For, in proportion as the body is capable
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of being affected in a greater variety of ways, and of affecting external
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: bodies in a great number of ways, so much the more is the mind capable of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thinking (IV:xxxviii., IV:xxxix.). But there seem to be very few things
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of this kind in nature; wherefore for the due nourishment of the body we
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: must use many foods of diverse nature. For the human body is composed of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: very many parts of different nature, which stand in continual need of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: varied nourishment, so that the whole body may be equally capable of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: doing everything that can follow from its own nature, and consequently
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that the mind also may be equally capable of forming many perceptions.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXVIII. Now for providing these nourishments the strength of each
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: individual would hardly suffice, if men did not lend one another mutual
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: aid. But money has furnished us with a token for everything: hence it is
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with the notion of money, that the mind of the multitude is chiefly
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: engrossed: nay, it can hardly conceive any kind of pleasure, which is not
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: accompanied with the idea of money as cause.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXIX. This result is the fault only of those, who seek money, not from
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: poverty or to supply their necessary, wants, but because they, have
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: learned the arts of gain, wherewith they bring themselves to great
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: splendour. Certainly they nourish their bodies, according to custom, but
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: scantily, believing that they lose as much of their wealth as they spend on
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the preservation of their body. But they who know the true use of money,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and who fix the measure of wealth solely with regard to their actual needs,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: live content with little.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXX. As, therefore, those things are good which assist the various parts
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the body, and enable them to perform their functions; and as pleasure
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consists in an increase of, or aid to, man's power, in so far as he is
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: composed of mind and body; it follows that all those things which bring
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasure are good. But seeing that things do not work with the object of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: giving us pleasure, and that their power of action is not tempered to suit
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: our advantage, and, lastly, that pleasure is generally referred to one
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: part of the body more than to the other parts; therefore most emotions of
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasure (unless reason and watchfulness be at hand), and consequently the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: desires arising therefrom, may become excessive. Moreover we may add that
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotion leads us to pay most regard to what is agreeable in the present,
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nor can we estimate what is future with emotions equally vivid.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (IV:xliv.Note, and IV:lx.Note.)
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXXI. Superstition, on the other hand, seems to account as good all that
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: brings pain, and as bad all that brings pleasure. However, as we said
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: above (IV:xlv.Note), none but the envious take delight in my infirmity
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and trouble. For the greater the pleasure whereby we are affected, the
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: greater is the perfection whereto we pass, and consequently the more do
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we partake of the divine nature: no pleasure can ever be evil, which is
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: regulated by a true regard for our advantage. But contrariwise he, who is
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: led by fear and does good only to avoid evil, is not guided by reason.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Ap.XXXII. (1) But human power is extremely limited, and is infinitely
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: surpassed by the power of external causes; we have not, therefore, an
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: absolute power of shaping to our use those things which are without us.
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Nevertheless, we shall bear with an equal mind all that happens to us
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in contravention to the claims of our own advantage, so long as we are
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conscious, that we have done our duty, and that the power which we possess
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is not sufficient to enable us to protect ourselves completely;
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: remembering that we are a part of universal nature, and that we
title: Ethics — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: follow her order. If we have a clear and distinct understanding of
title: Ethics — Part 4
